title: Lesson 17: Comparing Plant and Animal Cells
content:
Lesson 17: Comparing Plant and Animal Cells

A Tale of Two Eukaryotes

Both plants and animals are complex, multicellular life forms. Their cells have a nucleus, mitochondria, and all the other advanced machinery of a eukaryotic cell. But a tree and a tiger live very different lives! One is stationary and makes its own food, while the other moves around and eats. How are their cells specially designed to support these completely different lifestyles?

The Plant

Stationary, Makes Food

The Animal

Moves, Eats Food

Since they live so differently, their cells must be different too!

What They Have in Common: The Eukaryotic Toolkit

Before we look at the differences, it's important to remember that both plant and animal cells are **eukaryotic**. This means they share a lot of the same advanced machinery needed for complex life.

Plasma Membrane

Nucleus

Cytoplasm

Mitochondria

Endoplasmic Reticulum

Golgi Apparatus

Ribosomes

Lysosomes

The 3 Big Differences

Their different lifestyles require three major structural differences. These unique features are what truly separate a plant cell from an animal cell.

1. Cell Wall (Plants Have It, Animals Don't)

An animal has a skeleton for support. A plant does not. To provide strength and structure, a plant cell has a rigid outer **Cell Wall** made of cellulose. An animal cell only has a soft plasma membrane, which allows for flexibility and movement.

2. Chloroplasts (Plants Have Them, Animals Don't)

An animal gets its food by eating. A plant makes its own food using sunlight. To do this, a plant cell contains **Chloroplasts**, the green organelles that perform photosynthesis. Animal cells have no need for chloroplasts.

3. Vacuoles (Big in Plants, Small in Animals)

A plant needs a large water reserve. A mature plant cell has one enormous **central vacuole** that stores water and maintains turgor pressure. Animal cells do not need this large reserve, so their vacuoles are small, temporary, or absent altogether.

Summary Table: Head-to-Head

Feature Plant Cell Animal Cell
Cell Wall ✓ Present ✗ Absent
Chloroplasts ✓ Present ✗ Absent
Vacuole One, large central vacuole Small or absent
Shape Fixed, often rectangular/squarish Flexible, often round/irregular
Shared Organelles Both have a nucleus, plasma membrane, mitochondria, ER, etc.
questions:
Lesson 17: Cell Showdown

1. Name three key structures found in plant cells that are NOT found in animal cells.

Cell Wall

Chloroplasts

Large Central Vacuole

The three key structures are the **Cell Wall**, **Chloroplasts**, and the **large Central Vacuole**.

2. Why do animal cells typically have an irregular shape, while plant cells have a more fixed, rectangular shape?

The Reason: It all comes down to the presence or absence of a cell wall.

Plant Cell: The plant cell has a **rigid cell wall** on its outside, which acts like a strong box and gives it a fixed, often rectangular, shape.

Animal Cell: The animal cell lacks a cell wall. Its outermost layer is the **soft, flexible plasma membrane**, which allows it to have a more irregular or rounded shape.

3. A student claims that because plant cells have chloroplasts to make food, they do not need mitochondria. Is this student correct? Explain.

No, the student is incorrect. Plant cells absolutely need mitochondria.

The Analogy: A chloroplast is like a farm that produces raw crops (sugar). A mitochondrion is like a power plant that burns that fuel to create electricity (ATP).

Explanation: A plant cell cannot use the sugar it makes directly for energy. It must send that sugar to the mitochondria, which then perform cellular respiration to convert the food energy into usable ATP energy. Both organelles are essential for the plant's survival.

4. Look at the two cells below. Which is the plant cell and which is the animal cell? Name one feature that proves your answer.

Cell A

Cell B

- Cell A is the **Animal Cell**.
- Cell B is the **Plant Cell**.

Justification (Any one of these is correct):

  • Cell B has a rigid, rectangular shape due to its cell wall, which Cell A lacks.
  • You could also mention the presence of chloroplasts or a large central vacuole if they were drawn inside Cell B.

5. Complete the table with "Present" or "Absent".

OrganelleAnimal CellPlant Cell
Plasma Membrane??
Cell Wall??
Nucleus??
OrganelleAnimal CellPlant Cell
Plasma MembranePresentPresent
Cell WallAbsentPresent
NucleusPresentPresent

6. An organism's cells are observed to be eukaryotic and have cell walls but no chloroplasts. Is this organism a plant or an animal?

This organism is **neither** a plant nor an animal.

Reasoning: It cannot be an animal because animal cells don't have cell walls. It cannot be a typical plant because its cells lack chloroplasts. This organism is most likely a **fungus** (like a mushroom), as fungal cells have cell walls but do not perform photosynthesis.

7. Why is a large central vacuole much more important for a plant cell's survival than for an animal cell's survival?

A large central vacuole provides two things that are critical for a plant's lifestyle:

  1. Water Storage: A plant is stationary and cannot move to find water. It needs a large internal reservoir to survive periods of drought.
  2. Support: The vacuole provides turgor pressure against the cell wall, which gives the plant its rigidity and allows it to stand up. Animals get their support from skeletons instead.

8. You put a plant cell and an animal cell into a beaker of pure, distilled water (a hypotonic solution). What will be the final fate of each cell?

Animal Cell: It will take in water by osmosis, swell up, and **burst (lysis)** because it has no cell wall to protect it.

Plant Cell: It will take in water and swell, but its strong cell wall will prevent it from bursting. It will become **firm and turgid**.

9. Name two organelles that both plant and animal cells share because they are both eukaryotes.

Any two of the following are correct: **Nucleus, Mitochondria, Endoplasmic Reticulum, Golgi Apparatus, Plasma Membrane, Cytoplasm, Ribosomes.**

10. Draw a Venn diagram to compare Plant and Animal cells. Place at least one key feature in each of the three sections.

(Your answers may vary, e.g., you could put "Chloroplast" in Plant Only, "Mitochondria" in Both, etc.)
exercises:
Lesson 17: Cell vs. Cell Exercises

1. "Plant Only" Organelles

Name the three major organelles/structures that are typically found in a plant cell but are absent in an animal cell.

The three structures are the **Cell Wall**, **Chloroplasts**, and the **large Central Vacuole**.

2. What's My Shape?

A scientist observes a cell that is rounded and has an irregular shape. Is it more likely to be a plant cell or an animal cell? Why?

It is more likely to be an **Animal Cell**.

Reason: Animal cells lack a rigid cell wall, so their shape is flexible and often irregular. Plant cells have a rigid cell wall that gives them a more fixed, box-like shape.

3. Who's the Chef?

Which type of cell has its own "kitchen" (chloroplasts) to make its own food?

The **Plant Cell**.

4. Fill in the Blanks

Both plant and animal cells need energy, so both have the organelle known as the ____________. However, only plant cells have ____________ to capture sunlight.

mitochondria, chloroplasts.

5. Identify the Organelle Owner

For each organelle, decide if it belongs to "Plant Only," "Animal Only," or "Both."

  • Large Central Vacuole: ___________
  • Nucleus: ___________
  • Cell Wall: ___________
  • Large Central Vacuole: Plant Only
  • Nucleus: Both
  • Cell Wall: Plant Only

6. True or False?

The plasma membrane is found in plant cells but not in animal cells.

False.

**ALL** cells (plant and animal included) must have a plasma membrane to control what enters and exits. Plant cells just have an extra cell wall on the outside of their plasma membrane.

7. Which One Am I?

I am a eukaryotic cell. I contain mitochondria but no cell wall. I am probably a(n) _________ cell.

animal.

8. Survival Scenario

Two cells are dropped into pure, fresh water. One bursts, the other becomes firm. Which one was the plant cell, and what structure saved it?

The one that became firm was the **plant cell**.

What saved it: The rigid **cell wall** prevented it from bursting under the pressure of the incoming water.

9. Odd One Out

Which of these is a similarity between a plant and animal cell, not a difference?

(a) Both have chloroplasts. | (b) Both have a cell wall. | (c) Both have a nucleus.

(c) Both have a nucleus.

Reason: Both are eukaryotic cells, and the defining feature of eukaryotes is the presence of a nucleus.

10. True or False?

The presence of a large vacuole gives an animal cell its strength.

False.

Animal cells do not have large vacuoles, and they do not rely on them for strength (they rely on a skeleton). The large vacuole provides strength (turgor) to plant cells.

11. Concept Check

Can an animal cell perform photosynthesis? Why or why not?

No, an animal cell cannot perform photosynthesis.

Reason: Photosynthesis requires the organelle known as the chloroplast. Animal cells do not have chloroplasts.

12. Compare and Contrast

Describe the vacuole situation in both plant and animal cells.

Plant cells: Typically have one, very large central vacuole that can take up most of the cell's volume.

Animal cells: Have small, temporary vacuoles, or none at all.
intros:
Lesson 17: Comparing Plant and Animal Cells

We've toured all the major organelles. Now it's time for a head-to-head comparison! Plant and animal cells are both eukaryotes, but they live very different lives. How do their structures reflect these differences?

A Tale of Two Cities

Imagine a medieval walled fortress-city that grows its own food, versus a modern, sprawling city that has to import all its food and energy. How would they be built differently?

A **plant cell** is like the walled fortress. It needs strong outer walls for structure (**Cell Wall**). It has its own solar panels to make its own food (**Chloroplasts**). And it needs a massive water tower to maintain pressure and survive droughts (**large Central Vacuole**).

An **animal cell** is like the modern city. It has no need for a massive outer wall because animals have skeletons for support. It has no solar panels because it imports food. And it has no need for a huge water tower, as it gets a constant supply from the organism. While both have a city hall (nucleus) and power plants (mitochondria), their different lifestyles lead to these three major structural differences.

Form follows function: each cell is built perfectly for its unique way of life.

Two Different Lifestyles

A plant is stationary and makes its own food. An animal moves around and has to eat other things. How are their cells designed differently to support these lifestyles?

A plant is an autotroph (self-feeder), so its cells must contain **chloroplasts** to perform photosynthesis and make food. Animals are heterotrophs (other-feeders), so their cells don't have chloroplasts.

A plant needs to be rigid and stand up tall, so its cells have a strong **cell wall**. An animal needs to move, requiring its cells to be flexible, so they do not have a rigid cell wall. A plant may go long periods without water, so its cells have a **large central vacuole** to store it. An animal gets a more constant supply of water, so its cells have very small vacuoles, if any.

Different needs, different designs: The cell tells the story of the organism.

The Build-a-Cell Workshop

You have a basic "eukaryote" model kit with a nucleus and mitochondria. Which three key parts would you add to turn it into a PLANT cell?

Although both plant and animal cells share many common organelles (like the nucleus, ER, mitochondria), there are three key structures you find in plant cells but NOT in animal cells. To upgrade your basic model into a plant cell, you would need to add...

  • A rigid outer **Cell Wall** for support.
  • Green **Chloroplasts** to make food.
  • A huge **Central Vacuole** to store water and provide firmness.

An animal cell, on the other hand, is basically just the "base model" without these three special additions.

Three special parts transform a basic eukaryote into a powerful plant cell.

The Checklist Challenge

Let's play "spot the difference" at a cellular level! How would you fill out a feature checklist for a plant cell versus an animal cell?

Both plant and animal cells are eukaryotic, so they share a lot of organelles, like a nucleus, mitochondria, ER, and plasma membrane. You would tick "YES" for both cells on these features.

However, the major differences would show up on the rest of the checklist. For a plant cell, you would tick "YES" for having a **Cell Wall**, **Chloroplasts**, and a **large Central Vacuole**. For an animal cell, you would have to tick a firm "NO" for all three of these structures. It's these three key differences that truly set them apart.

Cell Wall, Chloroplasts, Central Vacuole: The three "NOs" on an animal cell's checklist.

Venn Diagram Adventure

If we put all the organelles into a Venn diagram, which parts would be unique to each cell, and which parts would they share?

A Venn diagram is the perfect way to compare plant and animal cells. In the shared middle section, we would put all the organelles they both have in common: a nucleus, cytoplasm, plasma membrane, mitochondria, ER, Golgi, and ribosomes. They are both complex eukaryotic cells, so they share a lot of the same basic machinery.

However, the key differences would lie in the un-shared sections. The "Plant Only" side would contain the **Cell Wall, Chloroplasts,** and a **Large Central Vacuole**. The "Animal Only" side is much smaller, but might contain specialized structures like centrioles (involved in division) or many small vacuoles instead of one large one.

Lots in common in the middle, but three huge differences on the outside.
summary:
Lesson 17: Comparing Plant and Animal Cells

Key Similarities and Differences

Visual Comparison of Eukaryotic Cells

Key Differences at a Glance

Feature Plant Cell Animal Cell
Cell Wall Present (made of cellulose) Absent
Shape Fixed, often rectangular shape Irregular, round shape
Plastids (Chloroplasts) Present Absent
Vacuole One large, central vacuole Small and numerous, or absent
Centrioles Absent (in higher plants) Present

What They Have in Common

Despite their differences, both plant and animal cells are eukaryotic and share many organelles, including:

Plasma Membrane Nucleus Cytoplasm Mitochondria Golgi Apparatus Endoplasmic Reticulum Ribosomes
